description:
After captured Leo Triplet, M66 seemed a good target for my 11" SCT. The shape of M66 looks like an Arabic numeral 6 in this image. Did Charles Messier see this way and listed it #66 in the catalog? The data was collected during the period of below-average seeing. I also collected Ha 48 frames of 900 seconds, however, I couldn't blend Ha into the Red channel due to lack of details. 
Any C & C are welcome
Thanks,
-- Facts ----
Messier 66 (a.k.a. NGC 3627) 
M66 is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation Leo, discovered by French astronomer Charles Messier in 1780. M66 is located 35 million light-years from Earth, has an apparent magnitude of 8.9, and is about 95 thousand light-years across with striking dust lanes and bright star clusters along sweeping spiral arms.

Technical details:
Telescope: Celestron Edge HD11 + Reducer 0.7x
Mount: AP Mach2GTO
Imaging cameras:ZWO ASI2600MM Pro
Software: PHD2, PixInsight, Lightroom 6.4, Sequence Generator Pro, Photoshop CS6
Location: Palo Alto, California, USA
PhotometricColorCalibration data (pre-corp):
Resolution ............... 0.198 arcsec/px
Rotation ................. -69.911 deg
Observation start time ... 2021-03-30 05:44:23 UTC
Observation end time ..... 2021-04-18 08:27:39 UTC
Focal distance ........... 1955.68 mm
Pixel size ............... 1.88 um
Field of view ............ 26' 7.4" x 19' 5.5"
Image center ............. RA: 11 20 17.490  Dec: +12 59 08.47     
Filters: Astrodon 1.25" LRGB Gen2 E-Series Filter Sets
Blue   106x300"          8.8 Hours  Bin1x1 
Green  106x300"          8.8 Hours  Bin1x1 
Red    97x300"           8 Hours    Bin1x1 
Lum    120x60" 200x120"  8.6 Hours  Bin1x1
title: Messier 66 (a.k.a. NGC 3627) - LRGB
